item.dc:creator: @darscape darscape
item.description:
@darscape wrote:

spawn npc + save to npc spawn table, dont have it remove after 60 seconds.

server keeps npcs in RAM, reloads as default on next load. Thats how it worked in ScapeRune

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Peter Peeter
item.description:
@Peter wrote:

I was thinking about this idea also… but ran into a wall.

How would you go about reloading new changes without a reboot?

a) Set all currently spawned grounditems, objects & npcs as not respawnable
b) Set their remove time to 60s, so everything is gone within 60 seconds.
c) Reload all changes after 60s.

This is just a theory, I’m wondering if anyone has tried this or can spot a flaw in it.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @ew_raped ew raped!
item.description:
@ew_raped wrote:

[quote=“Ecko, post:49, topic:321393”][quote author=Kryptix link=topic=417849.msg3073173#msg3073173 date=1261651275]
What’s your ideas?
[/quote]
Web-based player shops. They put items up, price and quantity, and anyone can buy at anytime. This can already be done without converting everything from XML.

Player-created NPC traders. Sort of like the Shops.xml file that generates all the shops in game. Players “purchase” an NPC which allows them to put items up for a certain price, and items they are looking for with the price/quantity they are willing to buy. All these NPCs could be in one marketplace, with sections for what they buy/sell. Sort of like a customized mule.[/quote]
So basicly we will generate the forum id of the user by $Username = pun_htmlspecialchars($pun_user[‘id’]);
Making a php bank/inv query to insert the certain data into the shop. then create a npc what checks the rscd_playershops by the search say “echo” what will read the rscd_players to get the forum id of that player then get the fields what are in the rscd_playershops sending the items and prices so on so on to the shop it preety much is a simple process but a kick ass idea +1 to you

public int add(InvItem item) { if(item.getAmount() <= 0) { return -1; } for(int index = 0;index < items.size();index++) { if(item.equals(items.get(index))) { items.get(index).setAmount(items.get(index).getAmount() + item.getAmount()); return index; } } items.add(item); return items.size() - 2; } To add the item such

item.dc:creator: @Ecko Ecko
item.description:
@Ecko wrote:

What’s your ideas?

Web-based player shops. They put items up, price and quantity, and anyone can buy at anytime. This can already be done without converting everything from XML.

Player-created NPC traders. Sort of like the Shops.xml file that generates all the shops in game. Players “purchase” an NPC which allows them to put items up for a certain price, and items they are looking for with the price/quantity they are willing to buy. All these NPCs could be in one marketplace, with sections for what they buy/sell. Sort of like a customized mule.

item.dc:creator: @Ecko Ecko
item.description:
@Ecko wrote:

I fail to see how this is a flaunting and “bragging” thread.

If you are going to be converting things from XML into MySQL, then I suggest not just stopping with locs/defs of objects/items/NPCs (ie - storing Shops.xml into its own table). If you are looking for web customization, then this is the way to go. There are a bunch of ideas I can already think of that would benefit from changing everything to MySQL. PM me if you are interested in hearing them.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Vrunk Vrunk
item.description:
@Vrunk wrote:

[quote=“Newty, post:29, topic:321393”]Banned.

No tears here bro…[/quote]

About time…I was a little disappointed when I found out that the mute I had given him was once again, lifted. (by who?)

As far as this topic goes - each method of storing data has its advantages/disadvantages, and it’s up to the developer to decide what works best for their specific situation. It is exceedingly easy to convert it between pure text, XML, MySQL, spreadsheets, binary, whatever - it all gets stored in RAM once the server is running anyways. Unless, of course, you retrieve the data from disk every time it is needed - which is completely unnecessary, seeing that all the data necessary to run a server will fit into a very small amount of RAM.

Read full topic
